entry.title: Re: How to handle ‚Äúusernames‚Äù, ‚ÄúGlobal User IDs‚Äù and ‚Äúexternal IDs‚Äù in your landscape?
entry.content:
Hello  @1Gunnar @dyaryura @Colt 

In a scenario with the following architecture:
Entra ‚Üí IAS ‚Üí SAC
Users are provisioned from Entra to IAS and then further to cloud applications (e.g., SAC). 

Users are authentificated in Entra.

SAP recommends in their documentation to take the Global User ID directly from IAS and distribute it to the cloud applications. How does this work when users authenticate via Entra?

My questions are:

  1. Should the Entra Object ID be mapped to the Global User ID (if users authenticate in Entra)?
  2. What value should be used in the NameID field (e.g., in SAC for SSO)?
    • Must this always be the Global User ID?
    • Or can it also be another attribute, such as EmployeeNumber?
  3. Regarding the Subject Name Identifier in IAS:

             - Should the Primary Attribute = Corporate Identity Provider = object_id  ?

              - Schould the Fallback Attribute = Identity Diretory = "user_uuid"  ?

 

     4. How can I get the Global User ID into the NameID field in SAC?

I am unsure how to best implement these points and would appreciate any advice or best practices.

Thank you very much in advance for your support !!!

Many Thanks and Best Regards

Can it be influenced through customizing? My goal is to make sure a batch cannot be assigned to multiple orders once it‚Äôs already used.

entry.title: Re: How to handle ‚Äúusernames‚Äù, ‚ÄúGlobal User IDs‚Äù and ‚Äúexternal IDs‚Äù in your landscape?
entry.content:
Hi tskwin,

Great question, this setup confuses many once Entra joins the chain. In an Entra ‚Üí IAS ‚Üí SAC scenario, Entra only takes care of authentication. The actual identity persists in the IAS Identity Directory, and that‚Äôs where the Global User ID (user_uuid) is generated and maintained, not in Entra.

Entra just hands over a token, IAS matches the user and enriches the identity with its own attributes. What really matters is user persistence in the Identity Directory and federation being enabled, once IAS receives the token from the authenticating IdP, it can issue a tailored token for the target application.

SAP‚Äôs recommendation to ‚Äúuse the Global User ID‚Äù simply means: make sure the UUID exists in IAS and that it can be passed on to cloud apps as an attribute. It does not mean the UUID must always be the NameID. In SAC, the NameID can stay email, EmployeeNumber, or whatever the app expects. The user_uuid is usually delivered as an additional claim rather than replacing the NameID.

For the Subject Name Identifier: from Entra to IAS you typically send something like email or UPN so IAS can find the user. From IAS to SAC, NameID should match the SAC setup, and the Global User ID can be added as a separate attribute. The Object ID from Entra is not a substitute for the IAS UUID.

In short: authenticate with Entra, persist and enrich identities in IAS, don‚Äôt overwrite the Global User ID, and only use it as NameID if a specific application actually requires it. That keeps you aligned with SAP‚Äôs architecture - and avoids an unnecessary identity meltdown üòâ

That‚Äôs how I currently understand it as well, but I‚Äôm also happy to wait and see what SAP officially comes back with üôÇ

Cheers Colt

entry.title: Joule Skill for Maintenance Order Management in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Disclaimer: This blog is created to showcase the Joule Skills feature in SAP and is intended for demonstration purposes only. The content is not meant for productive use.

This use case demonstrates the creation and deployment of Joule Skills in SAP Build to manage Maintenance Orders in SAP S/4HANA. By leveraging APIs from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub, the solution enables users to create, update, and retrieve maintenance orders through natural language interactions in Joule. The setup involves configuring input parameters, mapping them to action calls, and formatting responses, all while securely connecting the SAP BTP environment to the on-premise SAP S/4HANA system via Cloud Connector. This provides a seamless, conversational interface for maintenance order management, highlighting the capabilities of Joule Skills for process automation and intelligent interaction.

Prerequisite

  1. Establish a secure tunnel between the SAP BTP subaccount and the on-premise SAP S/4HANA system in Cloud connector. This allows the Joule skill to communicate with backend services (such as the Maintenance Order APIs) hosted in the on-premise system.
  2. After configuring the Cloud Connector to establish connectivity between the SAP BTP environment and the on-premise SAP S/4HANA system, the next step is to create a destination in the BTP subaccount.
    This destination acts as a connection point that allows applications (such as Joule skills or process automation projects) to call on-premise APIs securely through the Cloud Connector.

Begin by creating a custom action and selecting the required API from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. This API will be integrated into the Joule Skill to enable Maintenance Order Management through action calls. Once the action is created, choose the available operations. For this demonstration, the Maintenance Order ‚Äì POST, UPDATE, and PATCH methods are used to perform create, update, and retrieve functions. After adding these actions, test each one using the test feature and select the destination configured in the BTP cockpit.

 

In SAP Build Lobby, create a Joule Skills project and provide a suitable description for the skill. For example:

Create individual Joule skills for Maintenance Order ‚Äì POST/UPDATE and PATCH operations.

Create Maintenance Orders

Set up the input parameters for this Joule Skill, which will be used in the prompt during the demo of maintenance order creation from Joule. Next, create a destination variable to ensure the destination is correctly mapped upon project deployment. Map all necessary values from the input parameters to the respective inputs of the action call used for creating a maintenance order. Finally, proceed to the last step to format the response in Joule using the ‚ÄòSend Message‚Äô option.

Get Maintenance Order ‚Äì Joule Skill

Change Maintenance Order ‚Äì Joule Skill (Same as above)

After this release and deploy the project in the environment.Once deployed the version is reflected and launch the Joule

So by deploying the created joule skills we now have this feature by using natural language.

In conclusion, this demonstration highlights how Joule Skills in SAP Build can simplify Maintenance Order Management by enabling intuitive, natural language interactions with SAP S/4HANA. Through seamless integration using the Cloud Connector and APIs from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub, business users can efficiently create, update, and retrieve maintenance orders without navigating complex interfaces.

Demo Link

entry.title: What the Zimmer Biomet SAP S/4HANA project failure teaches us about governance in ERP transformation
entry.content:
The Zimmer Biomet SAP S/4HANA program

The Zimmer Biomet SAP S/4HANA program is one of the recent examples of the challenges large enterprises face during ERP transformations. Despite the experience of both the client and its implementation partner, Deloitte, the project resulted in significant operational disruption, financial impact, and ultimately a lawsuit valued at 172 million USD.

This case illustrates that even experienced organizations can face major risks when project governance is not clearly defined or enforced. The lessons from this example are highly relevant to SAP transformation programs based on SAP Activate and other structured methodologies

What happened?

Several governance and execution issues contributed to the project‚Äôs difficulties.

Business lack of readiness ignored under schedule pressure.
The program prioritized a go-live date over operational stability, leading to system instability and defects in core business processes.

Scope changes without sufficient control.
More than fifty change requests (51 to be exact) were introduced during delivery, reflecting weak initial planning and shifting priorities across the program.

Leadership transitions during critical phases.
The cutover took place amid workforce reductions and executive changes, disrupting oversight and decision-making at a critical stage.

High resource turnover and offshore dependency.
Frequent team changes and heavy reliance on offshore delivery compromised continuity and consistency and made team collaboration difficult.

Weak contractual governance.
The contract did not contain detailed acceptance criteria, performance metrics, or financial safeguards, which reduced the client‚Äôs ability to enforce quality and accountability.

These factors combined into a situation where accountability was fragmented, oversight weakened, and the project lost its alignment with business readiness.

Why Project Governance matters in SAP projects?

SAP Project Governance is far more than an administrative framework. It defines how decisions are made, validated, and enforced across all delivery phases, ensuring that the program remains transparent, disciplined, and aligned with both business objectives and delivery capabilities. A key element of governance is having clearly defined roles and responsibilities within the project organization. For project managers working within the SAP Activate framework, the ‚ÄúAgile Roles and Responsibilities‚Äù accelerator under the Establish Project Governance task provides detailed role definitions, a sample project structure, and supporting guidance for team setup.

Effective governance provides:

  • Clear project roles and responsibilities

  • Defined decision-making and escalation paths

  • Quality Gates (Q-Gates) and readiness checkpoints

  • Independent validation of progress and risk

  • A structured link between methodology and execution

Without this structure, even the most experienced teams are exposed to scope drift, political pressure, and decisions based on optimism rather than data.

Governance lessons learnt from the Zimmer Biomet's project

Zimmer Biomet‚Äôs experience highlights the importance of disciplined governance across all transformation phases. The following governance focus areas and controls can strengthen any SAP program:

1. Independent validation of plans and estimates.
Involve internal audit or a third-party reviewer to confirm delivery assumptions, timelines, and risk exposure before sign-off.

2. Contract governance and acceptance criteria.
Define measurable milestones, holdbacks, and acceptance conditions tied to business outcomes, not just technical completion.

3. Formal change control.
All scope changes should follow a documented approval process managed through a Change Advisory Board (CAB) or similar structure.

4. Tool-based governance workflows.
Use a project management tool to record requirements, approvals, and changes to maintain full traceability and transparency.

5. Quality Gates and readiness reviews.
Introduce Go/No-Go checkpoints in each SAP Activate phase to validate completion and business readiness before progressing.

6. Business readiness validation.
Conduct process simulations, data migration tests, and user readiness assessments before cutover to ensure the organization is prepared.

7. Post-Go-Live governance.
Establish clear escalation paths and service-level expectations for the stabilization (hypercare) period.

8. Independent audits.
Perform periodic reviews of deliverables versus commitments, and ensure know-how transfer to internal support teams before closure.

Governance, when properly applied, is not bureaucracy. It is the early-warning mechanism that detects risks before they escalate into operational issues.

 Conclusion

Zimmer Biomet‚Äôs experience demonstrates that project governance is not an optional formality and System Integrator's sole responsibility. It is the foundation of a controlled and transparent transformation that both contract parties should agree on and follow. Governance connects strategy to execution, defines accountability, and ensures that progress is validated objectively. All you have to do is to embed the discipline into your project with the help of SAP Activate framework.

Author

Bogdan G√≥rka ‚Äì Atlassian Solution Architect and SAP Project Governance consultant, creator of R2D ALM for Jira - a framework connecting SAP Activate methodology with Atlassian tooling. Independent consultant and founder of PMBG.EU Consulting.

entry.title: Unable to Resend Failed Transactions in SAP Business One Integration Framework (B1iF)
entry.content:
Dear All,

We are using SAP Business One Integration Framework (B1iF) to synchronize sales between SAP Customer Checkout (SCC) and SAP Business One. We are currently facing an issue where failed transactions cannot be resent after an initial processing failure.

Below are the details:

Scenario

  1. A transaction failed with the following error:
    com.sap.b1i.xcellerator.XcelleratorException: XCE001 Nested exception: com.sap.b1i.bizprocessor.BizProcException: BPE001 Nested exception: com.sap.b1i.xcellerator.XcelleratorException: XCE001 Nested exception: com.sap.b1i.xcellerator.XcelleratorException: XCE001 Nested exception: java.lang.RuntimeException: DI Error: (-10) Quantity falls into negative inventory [INV1.ItemCode][line: 1] - The di call #1 did fail.

  2. We corrected the stock levels by performing an inventory transfer to the affected warehouse.

  3. After that, we attempted to resend the transaction by using the Retry button in the Message Log window of the Integration Framework as shown below.

     

 

Actual Result

  • The invoice is not resent to SAP Business One.
  • The transaction entry is removed from the ‚ÄúProcessing Errors‚Äù tab in the Errors window, without being reprocessed.

Environment Details

  • SAP Business One: 10.0 FP 2405
  • Integration Framework (B1iF): Version 1.22.57
  • SAP Customer Checkout: Version 2.0

Request for Assistance

We would like to understand the correct procedure to successfully resend or reprocess a failed transaction once the root cause (such as insufficient stock) has been resolved.

Is there a recommended approach, configuration, or workaround to manually or automatically trigger the reprocessing of such failed SCC ‚Üí SAP B1 transactions?

Any guidance or best practices from the community would be greatly appreciated.

entry.title: Re: POSC is not picked by WPT
entry.content:
Hi,

regarding warehouse process type S010: you cannot use it for both unloading and putaway.

Check INB1 for warehouse 0001: unloading --> IB01 --> WPT 3065 and putaway --> IB03 --> WPT 1011

If I remember correctly (haven't used it in a while) the unloading step uses or can use the settings in transaction /SCWM/STADET_IN. 

Hope that helps

Andreas

PS POSC can be done with HUs only

When triggering the process, we get the following error message:

‚ÄúForm: YY1_PP_ETIQUETAFABRICACION is a legacy form and cannot be used with this API.‚Äù

see attached screenshot for details:

Stardard FormCustom Form

  • Is there a way to adapt or convert the form type so that it can be used?

  • Is this limitation expected for forms of this kind in Public Cloud?

Any insights, documentation links, or experiences with similar cases would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you in advance for your help!

Best regards,

ASG.

entry.title: Re: Service Layer ‚Äì Unable to Close Inventory Transfer Re...
entry.content: Hi everyone, Big thanks to the SAP Community ‚Äî and especially to Prasanth ‚Äî for pointing me in the right direction. Your guidance helped me resolve the persistent -1116 (Transaction notification) error when closing an Inventory Transfer Request via the Service Layer. What worked: I used the official close action: http Copy POST https://localhost:50000/b1s/v2/InventoryTransferRequests(123)/Close Content-Type: application/json {} Adding the empty JSON body {} was the key for the Service Layer to accept the POST. Additionally, I made a configuration change in our environment: I updated the b1s_sqltable.conf file to include the relevant tables used by this process ‚Äî OWTQ and WTQ1. After adding these tables, the close action completed without issues. Takeaways: Don‚Äôt PATCH the status directly; use the /Close action so SAP runs its full business logic. Ensure the document is open, the API user has the required permissions, and the request hasn‚Äôt already been fully copied to an Inventory Transfer. If you rely on SQL access through the Service Layer, confirm the necessary tables (in my case, OWTQ and WTQ1) are listed in b1s_sqltable.conf. Thanks again, Prasanth, and everyone who contributes here. Your help made all the difference!

entry.title: Test comment TCP1

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud Excel AddIn - Time Out Issue
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

we‚Äôre currently using the SAC Excel Add-In and are facing the following issue:

When a planner enters data in the Excel sheet, they need to click the ‚ÄúProcess Data‚Äù button to persist their entries. If they don‚Äôt, the Add-In automatically logs them out after a while, and any unprocessed data is lost.

We‚Äôre looking for a way to either extend the logout timer or ensure that entered data is automatically saved (as far as I know, only mass data entry is supported in the Excel Add-In). Any workaround other than using mass data entry would help solve this problem.

Has anyone encountered this issue or found a solution?

Kind regards,

Ismail

entry.title: Parallel accounting activation in future
entry.content:
Dear Cloud Public Edition experts,

I would like to ask clarification regarding the limitation and recommendation for scope item activation after Run phase (after go-live).

My customer has decided the activation of scope item 1GA (Accounting and Financial Close ‚Äì Group Ledger IFRS (1GA)) during the initial set-up phase.
However, some scope items like FI-AA matter (J62 and 1GB) are not taken into account yet.
My customer is now considering the activation in future because they have no clear business requirements as of now for IFRS treatment.

In current situation, does SAP recommend them to activate J62 and 1GB during the initial set-up phase? or after go-live when they have clear business requirements on FI-AA?

Thank you for your support & Kindly Regards,
Ai Takahashi

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 FPS00: Final What's New & Product Assistance
entry.content:
With immediate effect, the documentation for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 is available. You can find this documentation on the current SAP Help Portal pages of SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

To learn more about the changed and new features in SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025, access the What‚Äôs New information by using the following links:  What's New Viewer for SAP S/4HANA or What's New Viewer for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

For any feedback you may have, you can use the commenting feature for What's New.  With this feature, authors can evaluate your feedback and incorporate it into the documentation, if needed. We hope that by opening this channel of communication, we can learn how to further improve our What‚Äôs New content for you. To use this feature, you need to be logged into the SAP Help Portal. The feature is only available in the English version of the documents. To learn more about how the feedback process works in SAP Help Portal, see Giving Documentation Feedback.

I_APIsForCloudDevelopment

I_APIsWithCloudDevSuccessor

entry.title: Why Clients Say No to BTP ‚Äì and How to Change Their Mind
entry.content:
Hey BTP Community! Do you know that feeling? You walk into a meeting with an innovative idea, and the client‚Äîjust hearing "SAP BTP"‚Äîimmediately rejects it. "I don't want BTP implementation!" ‚Äì they exclaim, with a look of weariness in their eyes.

Too many times, innovation, instead of solving problems, becomes... a hot potato.

Sure, there are companies boasting a full migration to BTP, but the truth is, most organizations have concerns. Concerns about the new, about the cost, about too much detachment from the stable, "on-premise" world.

But today, I'll show you how to turn that "No" into "Why didn't we do this sooner?" I'm presenting a true case that proves, in certain scenarios, BTP is not just better; it's the only sensible and secure solution.

End Customers Straight into S/4HANA

Problem Analysis: When On-Premise "Knowledge and Familiarity" Becomes the Biggest Risk.

Imagine a typical scenario: A client needs a portal where their end customers (B2C/B2B) can verify the status of their service requests (or other object/s existing in the S/4HANA).

On-premise decision: We create external user accounts directly in the S/4HANA system. We define roles just like for internal users. We have advanced control and know the system inside out. Sounds good, right?

This approach, while familiar, introduces critical risks and burdens:

  1. Security Risk: This is my biggest headache. An external user, even with the most restrictive role, works on the same system as critical business processes and your internal employees. There is a risk (or its perception) that the user will gain access to data they shouldn't. This discomfort is a real threat to your company.

  2. Performance Issues: Suddenly, your customers start working on the same system as your business processes! Increased traffic, planned jobs, mass status verifications... all of this burdens S/4HANA. Planning for increased resource consumption is required.

  3. Additional Team Workload: Every request regarding access problems, passwords, or end-customer permissions lands on your Security/Basis team's desk. This burdens them, diverting them from key maintenance and development tasks.

The "SAP Plumber" Architecture: Why Are Customers Waiting in the Dark?

This scenario was further complicated by inefficient integration processes:

  1. The Customer creates a request in an old, external Legacy System (Success - 200 - Request Created in the Lagacy System).
  2. The request is saved in the Legacy Database (Status: "Staging").
  3. The Legacy System processes requests and transfers them (via API) to S/4HANA at intervals.

And here the drama begins:

  • S/4HANA REJECTS some requests for various reasons (business rules, technical errors, missing data).
  • The client receives no feedback. They just wait. And then they wait some more.
  • Finally, the request lands on the servisk desk of... System Maintenance Experts! (Our "SAP Plumber" üîß). They painstakingly verify errors, push through messages, and waste valuable time on tasks that should be automated.

The result? Low customer satisfaction, increased pressure, and prioritization of requests that were never even processed in the first place!

 The Solution You Need: Client Portal on SAP BTP

Isolation, Visibility, Scalability ‚Äì The Three True Benefits of BTP.

Client portals are an ideal, canonical use case for SAP BTP!

How does it work, technically and business-wise?

1. Isolation and Security 

  • We deploy a new Portal Application (e.g., based on SAP CAP in Node.js or Fiori/UI5) on SAP BTP.
  • End customers log in ONLY to BTP. Their accounts, users, and traffic are completely isolated from the critical S/4HANA system
  • Key logic and statuses are handled outside the ERP, in a secure BTP environment.

 

 

2. Full Request Status Visibility

  • The BTP application integrates with the Legacy system. Since SAP CAP is Node.js, we can:

    •  

      Consume existing Legacy APIs.
    • Or, if no API exists, connect directly to the Legacy Database (using the appropriate driver).
  • From the moment a request is created, the client sees its FULL and CURRENT status, directly in the BTP application.
  • (Such app is also helpfull for technical persons)
  • S/4HANA Integration: If necessary, we use secure OData APIs from S/4HANA (read-only or controlled write access) to fetch additional, approved information (e.g., invoice number, agent name). Controlled APIs are your gateway, not an open door!

3. Unleashing Data Potential

  • A bonus that is often overlooked: If we decide to use HANA DB on BTP, we automatically gain the ability to easily consume and analyze data from the Client Portal in analytical tools such as SAP DataSphere, SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), or Business Data Cloud (BDC).

  • Creating reports, tracking progress, measuring satisfaction, and identifying bottlenecks becomes trivially simple.

Break Client Resistance. Turn "No" into "I Need This."

A client who says "No to BTP" is actually saying:

  • "I don't want additional costs."
  • "I don't want complications."
  • "I don't understand how this will help me."

My answer:
"BTP is not an end goal; BTP is a tool that eliminates critical architectural and business risks."

When integration is so strongly tied to the SAP S/4HANA ecosystem, and the requirements are data isolation and scalability ‚Äî  SAP BTP is good choice.

Leave Kudos if You like it üôÇ

entry.title: Creating a BP (Customer Role) and Associating a Company
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I‚Äôm currently working on a project where I need to create a Business Partner in SAP and assign the Customer role (ZFLCU0) to it. I have the code working for these parts, but I‚Äôm struggling with the last step ‚Äî associating a company to the Business Partner.

Here is the code I have so far, which is functional:

ls_central-SEARCHTERM1 = customer-name1.
ls_central-PARTNERTYPE = 'GE00'.
APPEND ls_central TO lt_central.

" Create Business Partner
CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_BUPA_CREATE_FROM_DATA'
  EXPORTING
    partnercategory = '1'
    centraldata = ls_central
  IMPORTING
    business_partner = lv_bpartner
  TABLES
    return = lt_return.

" Assign Customer Role (ZFLCU0)
CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_BUPA_ROLE_ADD'
  EXPORTING
    businesspartner = lv_bpartner
    businesspartnerrole = 'ZFLCU0'
  TABLES
    return = lt_return.

" Commit creation and changes
CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT'
  EXPORTING
    wait = abap_true.

Thanks in advance for your help!

entry.title: Early Adopter Care - Extend Latest People Profile with BTP Custom Cards
entry.content:
Extending People Profile with data that is specific to your company's employees is something that a large majority of SuccessFactors customers use already. Getting a 360 degree view of the employee data is something that is at the heart of People Profile. With MDF custom objects we have always provided such in-app extension capability in People Profile and it is used by more than 75% of customers.  Now we take this a step further and enable side-by-side extensions with BTP custom cards, which allow to display employee data from BTP extensions in Full Profile of Latest People Profile.

Including employee data available on BTP into Full Profile via BTP custom cards is available with the 2H 2025 release for early adopter care customers. Please see the schematic picture of such side-by-side extensions:

The creation of such extension is triggered from the Configure Latest People Profile page via the Extensibility Wizard, which is the new common entry point for creating extensions across SAP Business Suite. As long as your BTP extension provides an API, you will be able to access this data from a UI Integration Card, which is implemented in SAP Business Application Studio in SAP Build and is then deployed to SuccessFactors. Once deployed, it can be added to Full Profile in any category.

If you have BTP-based extensions with employee data that you would like to make available in People Profile, then you are a candidate for our Early Adopter Care program, which starts with the 2H 2025 release. There are some prerequisites to participate in the program:

  • You have a BTP Global Account on Cloud Foundry and a SAP Build license.
  • You have an extension application running in a BTP subaccount (or plan to build one). E.g., an application developed with SAP Build Apps or SAP Build Code. The application provides an API that can be called from a UI Integration Card implemented in Business Application Studio. Typically, this would be a REST or OData API.
  • You have implemented IAS in SuccessFactors.
  • Full Profile in Latest People Profile is active in your SuccessFactors instance. Full Profile is opt-out with 2H 2025.

There are a few restrictions with this capability in this very first release.

  • BTP Custom Cards only support view mode.
  • We recommend that BTP custom cards have the same height as regular cards in Full Profile. This allows for a consistent UI experience.
  •  Links in custom cards will always open a new window or tab.

If you fulfill the prerequisites and would like to try this new extension capability as an early adopter care customer, please contact @stockp via direct message here in the community or via email to peter.stock@sap.com. We can provide you additional material around this capability and carry out the qualification for this program.

Take advantage of this opportunity for your company to engage directly with SAP development and the Product Management teams. As part of this initiative, you will have the opportunity to actively participate in shaping the functionality over the next several months until it becomes generally available (GA). Registration is open now!

entry.title: 2H2025 - Introducing Public Content Links: Seamless Static Content Hosting in SuccessFactors
entry.content:
In the previous versions of SuccessFactors, administrators had to contact Technical Support to host static content publicly, which was often time-consuming and required additional support.

With the 2H2025 release, SuccessFactors has introduced a new feature that streamlines this process, allowing administrators to host static content directly from the Admin Center.

Let‚Äôs explore the new Public Content Links feature and how it can revolutionize your static content management. üí°

In the Admin Center administrators now have the capability to access a dedicated Public Content Links page.

The feature allows users to upload or replace static content, which is then hosted in a public directory accessible to anyone with the link. It will replace the cumbersome support process and will empower administrators to fulfill their tasks at any time without any process delays

What Prerequisites do you have to consider?

Before using this feature, ensure that you meet the following prerequisites:

Grant the necessary permissions

As the documents will be publicly accessible, only few dedicated administrators in a company should get access to this feature. Therefore, we introduced 2 new Role-Based Permissions (Manage Permission Roles --> Administrator Permissions --> Admin Center Permissions --> Static Content File Hosting) that need to be granted:

You can distinguish between just having the upload permission or having both the upload and replace permissions:

1. **Upload**: Permits users to upload new content and generate public links.
2. **Replace**: Permits users to replace existing content by providing its public link.

Enable Email Notifications

If a user uploads a file to be publicly hosted a public link to access this file will be generated. After the upload the link will be shown in the UI, but it will also be send to the user via an email. To receive that email, the email notifications need to be enabled for the administrator. 

This can be verified through Admin Center --> Change User Email Notification.

Additionally, users must enable email notifications in their profile settings under Settings (profile icon) --> Notifications --> Send emails to me.

                               

The Doing - How to Upload or Replace Static Content

As mentioned before, the newly introduced Public Content Links feature enables administrators to upload new content as well as replace existing existing content. 

Upload New Static Content

Uploading new content is pretty straight forward in the Public Content Links page.

The administrator can select the file that shall be uploaded, and add a description if necessary. 

Additionally, the administrators have to confirm our "terms and conditions", which are:

  • SAP offer this service for documents used in the SAP SuccessFactors context only. SAP reserves the right to delete any files it determines are used for impermissible purposes, or if the Customer's SAP SuccessFactors Cloud Service subscription is terminated. 
  • The URL we generate will provide access to the file without any additional permission check, as the documents are hosted on a publicly available directory.
  • The customer has to represent that they have all necessary rights to use and share the file.
  • It needs to be confirm that this file will not be treated as or include Confidential Information.

By accepting the terms and conditions and clicking the upload button, the document will be sent to the hosting directory. Before that happens, there'll be one final confirmation message to ensure you're absolutely sure about the upload. We get it, nobody likes too many steps üòâ, but we strongly believe that uploading a file from an HR system to a public directory should be a mindful process.

After the upload the user gets a confirmation message that includes the link to access the file:

Because the link disappears when the user closes the dialog box, an email containing the link is also sent:

Replace Existing Static Content

Replacing an already hosted file with a new one is as easy as uploading a new file. There are only 2 additional pieces of information needed on the Public Content Links page:

The administrator can select the file that shall be uploaded, and add a description if necessary - both actions are the same as when uploading a new file.

The administrator now needs to enable the toggle Replace Existing File. With that a new, mandatory input field "Existing File URL" will show up on the page. The user can input the URL of the previously hosted content that he wants to replace with the new file.
Having done that, the terms and conditions need to be confirmed again.

Clicking the Upload button will show a popup to confirm the action as well as inform the user that although the file will be replaced by the new one, the existing URL will stay the same. So, if the name of the file is different to the one that shall be replaced, this will not be reflected in the URL, as you can see in the screenshot of the confirmation message below. 

When the administrator confirms by clicking the Upload button, the existing hosted file will be replaced by the newly uploaded one and a success message will be displayed. For completeness the success message as well as the confirmation email sent out to the user will include the URL again, although it hasn't changed.

What's not in (yet)? - Restrictions and Limitations

Similar to the former static content file hosting by SAP SuccessFactors Support organization, there are some limitations and restrictions you need to consider:

File Type and File Size Limitations

The Public Content Links self-service tool supports the following:

  • Videos: mp4 (up to 100 MB)
  • Images: jpg/jpeg/png (up to 1 MB)
  • Documents: pdf/doc/docx/ppt/pptx/csv/xls/xlsx (up to 10 MB)

Access Restrictions

This feature is not accessible when acting as a proxy. Only the logged-in user‚Äôs own session allows access to the Public Content Links tool.

(Current) Functional Tool Limitations

In the 2H2025 functional scope the self-service tool provides the option to upload and replace files, however it does not support deleting uploaded files. This means, if you for whatever reason have uploaded the wrong file or replaced a file with a wrong file, you cannot delete this wrongly uploaded content. As a workaround we suggest to replace the wrongly uploaded file with an (empty) dummy file and not sharing the URL.

We are planning to provide the deletion functionality in the next release 1H2026.

Also not yet available in the 2H2025 release is an overview of all publicly hosted documents of a customer. This is also planned to be included in the next release.

Migration of already hosted files, uploaded prior 2H2025

Although, the Public Content Links tool will replace the former process via support ticket, there is no migration of the already hosted files planned, that were uploaded prior 2H2025.

In case you like to replace an already hosted file, you still need to create a support ticket. 

Saying that I would assume you know all the important facts to be ready for using the new self-service tool. 

I hope this service makes the daily life of your administrators easier and increases their efficiency and happiness üòâ.

You might want to check out the additional resources:

WNV: Public Links for Hosting Static Content 

Documentation: Uploading Static Content and Generating a Public Link and Replacing Existing content at a Public Link 

Stay tuned for more updates on Document Management soon! üëç

entry.title: Re: Product Master Classification
entry.content:
Dear @MR71,

Option A: Custom field on Product

            Setup:

  1. Custom Fields‚Üí create field on Product Master as a Code List with 5 fixed values (e.g., 1‚Äì5 or A‚ÄìE with labels).
  2. Enable it for UIs/Services and Publish.
  3. In Manage Product Master Data, adapt the UI to show the field.

Result:

  • On the Product screen (your added section/field).
  • Build a list/report via Custom CDS View (join Product basic data; add your custom field) and save as a tile.
  • You can also filter by the field in product and stock apps once exposed.

 

Option B: Classification with a 5-value characteristic

Setup:

  1. Manage Characteristics ‚Üí create CATEGORY with 5 allowed values.
  2. Manage Classes ‚Üí create MATERIAL_CLASS and assign the characteristic.
  3. Classify Products ‚Üí assign the class to products and set the value in manage product master data in classification tab

Result:

  • Add to analytics with a Custom CDS View / Custom Analytical Query that reads product classifications.

Best Regards

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Creating a BP (Customer Role) and Associating a Company
entry.content:
To associate a company (i.e., assign company code data to the Business Partner), you need to create customer company code data using the appropriate BAPI. The BAPI you're currently using (BAPI_BUPA_CREATE_FROM_DATA) only creates the general Business Partner record. Assigning a company requires customer-specific data under a company code.

You should use BAPI_CUSTOMER_CREATEFROMDATA1 after assigning the customer role where

  • ls_companydata includes the company code and other financial data.
  • ls_companydatadetail includes payment terms, reconciliation account, etc.

Alternatively, if the Business Partner already exists and you just want to extend it to a company code, use BAPI_CUSTOMER_CHANGEFROMDATA1. After assigning company data, don‚Äôt forget to commit
